content.renderedOutput:
Introduction

Path Stroke Tessellates strokes of any collection of polygons of any type

Path is a modern interface for vector graphics, where you can define multiple paths with tools such as:

  1. Lines, Rectangles
  2. Bezier curves
  3. Elliptic arcs And then you can tessellate them automatically using:
  4. Fill Tessellation Planar Subdivision
  5. Stroke Tessellation Stroke Tessellation

It is best to see the example of usage below.

Notes:

  • Self contained and
    does not require stdlib
  • After Fill or Stroke Tessellation, internal buffers are cached, so re-tessellation will happen only if something is invalid. This is done to save energy.
  • Internal cache buffers can be drained using the
    drainBuffers()
     method
  • Numerically stable. Can tessellate with any number precision:
    Q
     (fixed point),
    float
     and
    double
  • Path
     is Allocator-aware through construction so you can use it in any computer memory model (even on the stack)
  • Optional boundary info output

Input

Input to the algorithm is

  • Stroke Width
     value
  • Stroke Cap
     enum
    microtess::stroke_cap
  • Stroke Line Join
     enum
    microtess::stroke_line_join
  • Miter Limit
     value
  • Stroke Dash Array
     container to specify dashes pattern
  • Dash Offset
     value

Output

The algorithm outputs a

buffers
struct which holds containers for
vertices
,
indices
,
triangles type
,
boundary info

Debugging

If you are seeing bugs with the tessellation, try the following

  • Try increasing the precision of the
    number
    type of the vertices:
    • If using
      Q
      , try increasing precision bits. Q<8> -> Q<15>
    • If using
      float
      , then try
      double
       etc..

Example

taken from

examples/example_draw_path_stroke.cpp

The example demonstrates usage of different linear containers (including the packaged non standard

dynamic_array
), also a usage with a static array, that manages all memory on the stack.

The example also demonstrates different number types such as fixed point

integer(
Q
 numbers), float and doubles. Of particular interest is
Q<4>
, a very low 4 bit precision, that can compute the tessellation, This is the first published tessellator, that can do that. Tessellation computation is only few lines of code.

I use the

microgl
project to render the tessellation.

Tessellation is happening at line

#60

1//#define MICROGL_USE_STD_MATH
2#define MICROGL_USE_EXTERNAL_MICRO_TESS
3#include "src/example.h"
4#include <microgl/canvas.h>
5#include <microgl/bitmaps/bitmap.h>
6#include <microgl/pixel_coders/RGB888_PACKED_32.h>
7#include <microgl/samplers/flat_color.h>
8
9#include <micro-tess/path.h>
10#include <micro-tess/dynamic_array.h>
11#include <micro-tess/static_array.h>
12#include <vector>
13
14using microtess::path;
15
16template<class item, class fake_allocator>
17using static_array_with_fake_allocator = static_array<item, 10000, fake_allocator>;
18
19template<typename number>
20//using path_t = path<number, static_array_with_fake_allocator, std_rebind_allocator<>>;
21//using path_t = path<number, std::vector, std_rebind_allocator<>>;
22using path_t = path<number, dynamic_array, std_rebind_allocator<>>;
23
24template <typename number>
25path_t<number> path_star() {
26    path_t<number> path{};
27    path.lineTo({150, 150})
28        .lineTo({450, 150})
29        .lineTo({200,450})
30        .lineTo({300,50})
31        .lineTo({400,450})
32        .closePath();
33    return path;
34}
35
36int main() {
37    // using number = float;
38    // using number = double;
39    // using number = Q<8>;
40    // using number = Q<8>;
41    // using number = Q<14, long long>;
42    // using number = Q<12, int32_t>;
43    // using number = Q<4, int64_t>;
44    using number = Q<4, int32_t, int32_t, 0>;
45
46    // microgl drawing setup START
47    using Canvas24 = canvas<bitmap<RGB888_PACKED_32>>;
48    using il = std::initializer_list<int>;
49    sampling::flat_color<> color_red {{255,0,255,255}};
50    sampling::flat_color<> color_green {{22,22,22,255}};
51    Canvas24 canvas(640, 480);
52    // microgl drawing setup END
53
54    constexpr auto debug = false;
55    number offset = 0;
56
57    auto render_path = [&](path_t<number> & path) {
58        offset+=number(0.125f);
59        // Algorithm START
60        const auto & buffers= path.template tessellateStroke<>(
61                number(12), // stroke width
62                microtess::stroke_cap::round,
63                microtess::stroke_line_join::round,
64                10, // miter limit
65                il{50, 50}, // dash container
66                int(offset)); // dash offset
67        // Algorithm END
68
69        canvas.clear({255, 255, 255, 255});
70        canvas.drawTriangles<blendmode::Normal, porterduff::FastSourceOverOnOpaque, true>(
71                color_green,
72                matrix_3x3<number>::identity(),
73                buffers.output_vertices.data(),
74                static_cast<vertex2<number> *>(nullptr),
75                buffers.output_indices.data(),
76                buffers.output_boundary.data(),
77                buffers.output_indices.size(),
78                buffers.output_indices_type,
79                122);
80        if(debug)
81            canvas.drawTrianglesWireframe({0, 0, 0, 255},
82                               matrix_3x3<number>::identity(),
83                               buffers.output_vertices.data(),
84                               buffers.output_indices.data(),
85                               buffers.output_indices.size(),
86                               buffers.output_indices_type,
87                               255);
88    };
89
90    auto render = [&](void*, void*, void*) -> void {
91        static auto path = path_star<number>();
92        render_path(path);
93    };
94
95    example_run(&canvas, render);
96}
97
